Bibliothek Rechenzentrum Verwaltung Prof. Dr. Möller English · Deutsch Chair of Economics (Empirical Macroeconomics and Regional Economics) Faculty of Business, Economics and Management Information Systems Home Teaching Research Team Contact Lectures Seminars Theses VVZ WS 13/14 VVZ SS13 Other All courses of the faculty Only Bachelor Phase 1 Only Bachelor Phase 2 Only Diploma Only Bohemicum All courses of the faculty Only Bachelor Phase 1 Only Bachelor Phase 2 Only Diploma Only Bohemicum Ordered by institutes, etc. Links Lecture Rooms semester calendar Teaching Lectures Einführung in STATA Introduction to STATA Content This course aims to acquaint students with STATA, an econometric software package commonly used for data analysis. In addition to the command structure the course captures the preparation of the datasets for empirical assessment. Numerous problem sets and empirical examples are offered in order to apply and deepen the things learned before. Requirements Knowledge of basic econometric concepts is required because the theoretical concepts cannot be treated in the tutorial. Advanced knowledge is not necessary. With respect to room capacity, the course is open to anyone who is interested. Courses offered and exam The offer comprises computer-tutorial of 2 hours per week which can be attended in each semester. The final exam lasts 60 minutes (2 credit points) and is offered each semester in the regular audit period. The course can be attended by Bachelor students as well. Script Einführung in die Datenanalyse mit STATA Dates and rooms Tutorial: Wednesday, 12.15-13.45, RWL U 01 rechts Timeline: see blackboard Material for the course (slides and data files) can be found on the E-learning-platform. Webmaster · Intern

Regionalökonomie II Kontakt Impressum Datenschutz Navigation Studium Fakultäten Aktuelles Alumni Europaeum Forschung Internationales Klinikum Kultur und Freizeit Mensa Presse RUL Sportzentrum Sprachenzentrum Studierende aktiv Universität Hilfe... Bibliothek Rechenzentrum Verwaltung Prof. Dr. Möller English · Deutsch Lehrstuhl für Volkswirtschaftslehre (Empirische Makroökonomie und Regionalökonomie) Fakultät für Wirtschaftswissenschaften Home Lehre Forschung Team Kontakt Vorlesungen Seminare Abschlussarbeiten VVZ SS13 VVZ WS 13/14 Weitere Gesamtverzeichnis Wiwi Nur Bachelor Phase 1 Nur Bachelor Phase 2 Nur Diplom Nur Bohemicum Gesamtverzeichnis Wiwi Nur Bachelor Phase 1 Nur Bachelor Phase 2 Nur Diplom Nur Bohemicum Vorlesungsverzeichnisse nach Instituten etc. Links Hörsaalinfo Semesterkalender Lehre Vorlesungen Regionalökonomie II Regionalökonomie II Inhalt Die Veranstaltung bietet einen weiterführenden Blick in neuere regionalökonomische Modelle und empirische Untersuchungen. Den theoretischen Kern bildet das bereits in Regionalökonomie I angesprochene Kern-Peripherie-Modell, das nun formal hergeleitet wird. Aus empirischer Sicht werden unter anderem Fortschritte in der Messung und Bewertung von räumlichen Spezialisierungsmustern vorgestellt. Voraussetzungen Voraussetzung für den Besuch der Veranstaltung sind Kenntnisse grundlegender ökonomischer und ökonometrischer Konzepte. Der vorherige Besuch der Bachelor-Veranstaltung zur Regionalökonomie ist wünschenswert. Kursangebot und Klausur Die Veranstaltung umfasst eine Vorlesung und eine Übung im Umfang von jeweils 2 SWS und wird turnusgemäß im Wintersemester angeboten. Die 90-minütige Klausur (6 KP) wird in jedem Semester im üblichen Prüfungszeitraum angeboten. Sie ist für Erst- und Zweitschreiber geöffnet. Termine und Hörsäle (WS 2013/14) Vorlesung: Montag, 12.30-14.00, H13 Übungsgruppe 1: Montag, 10.15-11.45, H 7 Übungsgruppe 2: Mittwoch, 10.15-11.45, H 21 Eine genauere Fachbeschreibung der Regionalökonomie finden Sie hier. Der Zugang zu den Kursmaterialen befindet sich auf der E-Learning-Plattform GRIPS. Webmaster · Intern

Bibliothek Rechenzentrum Verwaltung Prof. Dr. Möller English · Deutsch Chair of Economics (Empirical Macroeconomics and Regional Economics) Faculty of Business, Economics and Management Information Systems Home Teaching Research Team Contact Lectures Seminars Theses VVZ SS13 VVZ WS 13/14 Other All courses of the faculty Only Bachelor Phase 1 Only Bachelor Phase 2 Only Diploma Only Bohemicum All courses of the faculty Only Bachelor Phase 1 Only Bachelor Phase 2 Only Diploma Only Bohemicum Ordered by institutes, etc. Links Lecture Rooms semester calendar Teaching Lectures Regionalökonomie II Regional Economics II Content The course offers a deeper insight in recent models of Regional Economics and empirical research. Its theoretical focus lies in the core-periphery-model which has already been treated in the Bachelor course and which is now derived formally. From the empirical perspective progress in the measurement and assessment of spatial patterns of specialisation are presented. Requirements Knowledge of basic economic and econometric concepts is required. It is recommended - but not required - to have attended the Bachelor course Regional Economics I. The course language is German, but during tutorials, questions can also be asked in English. Courses offered and exam The course comprises one lecture and one tutorial of 2 hours per week each which can be attended in winter term. The final exam lasts 90 minutes (6 credit points) and is offered each semester in the regular audit period. In both the summer term and the winter term the exam is open for students who take it for the first time. Dates and rooms (winter term 2012/13) Lecture: Monday, 12.30-14.00, H 13 Tutorial group 1: Monday, 10.15-11.45, H 7 Tutorial group 2: Wednesday, 12.15-13.45, VG 005 A detailled description of Regional Economics (in German) can be found here. Access to the slides and material for the tutorials can be found on the E-learning-platform. Webmaster · Intern

Bibliothek Rechenzentrum Verwaltung Prof. Dr. Heinrich English · Deutsch Department of Management Information Systems Faculty of Business, Economics and Management Information Systems Home Team Teaching Research Research Datenqualitaet Chair of Information Systems II Data quality In recent years, many novel and innovative topics (such as data warehouse systems, customer relationship management (CRM), and online social networks) have given rise to a high relevance of data quality issues in theory and practice. This is due to the fact that for users of data and especially decision makers, the benefit of data depends heavily on its completeness, correctness, consistency, and currency, respectively. Moreover, many studies deal with the costs and problems of bad data quality for firms and illustrate impressively the relevance of data quality. For example, according to an international survey on data quality, 75% of all respondents have made wrong decisions due to incorrect data. Therefore, the respondents and their staff spend up to 30% of their working time checking the correctness of the provided data (Harris Interactive 2006). Furthermore, 67% of marketing managers think that the satisfaction of their customers suffers from bad data quality (SAS Institute 2003). In this respect, the consequences of bad data quality are manifold: they range from insufficient decision support for managers to worsening customer relationships and customer satisfaction. Against this background, the quantification and improvement of data quality currently finds a great deal of attention in science and practice. Nevertheless, there are two fundamental questions that are often ignored in the analyses: (1) Are the data quality measures already implemented economically worthwhile? (2) When and to what extent are data quality investments reasonable? Therefore, amongst others we focus on the following research questions: To what extent do quality measures improve the data quality level and what are their economic consequences? When and to what extent shall firms invest in data quality measures from an economic point of view? The growing relevance of data quality has also revealed the need for adequate measurement. Here, quantifying the current state of data quality (e.g. of customer data) is essential to plan and value data quality measures. However, there is a lack of well-founded, applicable data quality metrics. Therefore, amongst others we address the following research questions: How can data quality be quantified by means of metrics in a well-founded way? How can such metrics be used to support an efficient management of data quality? Webmaster · Intern

Bibliothek Rechenzentrum Verwaltung Prof. Dr. Heinrich English · Deutsch Department of Management Information Systems Faculty of Business, Economics and Management Information Systems Home Team Teaching Research Prof. Dr. Heinrich Research Standards Chair of Information Systems II Decision models for an economic-oriented standard adoption Communication and technology standards play an increasingly important role in times of global value added networks. Especially from a business informatics view, that deals with the design and implementation of information systems, the question when to implement what standard is of very high relevance. In this respect, not only technical aspects of standards have to be considered as these are in most cases not crucial for standard diffusion. But instead the economic consequences of adopting a standard as well as the corresponding risks have to be taken into account adequately. On the one hand, introducing a standard may lead to savings in communication costs for an actor (e.g., firm); on the other hand, adopting a standard earlier than other actors may lead to first-mover-advantages, but implies also a high risk of sunk (investments) costs if other actors do not introduce the standard as expected. Thus, the actors' standardization decisions depend heavily on each other. Thereby, the network effects result in a coordination problem - the so-called standardization problem. In this regard, we focus on the following research questions: How can an individual actor anticipate the other decisions on the adoption of a standard in a network of autonomous actors (firms)? To what extent can inefficient decisions on the introduction of standards be avoided by anticipating the other actors' decisions, respectively? How can inefficient decisions on the adoption of standards be avoided in a network of autonomous actors (firms) using centralized coordination mechanisms and incentives? Webmaster · Intern
